title: Triple gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Video. In this unusual mechanism three gears mesh together in pairs, and yet they can turn! If you take three ordinary gears and put them together so that each gear meshes with the other two, then none of the gears can turn because neighbouring gears must turn in opposite directions. Triple gear avoids this problem by having the three "gears" arranged like linked rings - the gears then rotate along skew axes, and the opposite direction rule no longer applies (although see also Oskar van Deventer's Magic Gears for another possible solution). This is joint work with Saul Schleimer. We were inspired by another of Oskar's designs, his Knotted Gear, which consists of two linked rings that gear with each other, and of course we wondered if it would be possible to do three linked rings! Paper describing the mathematics behind the Triple gear, and how we designed it. Triple gear (solid) is a non-hollow version, which should make it easier to produce on a home printer. Baseplate and axle for Triple gear is designed to work with this, and gives a way to drive the gears using a motor. For axles without the baseplate or motor fitting, see 15cm axle for Triple gear and 30cm axle for Triple gear. Triple gear is also available at Shapeways. Things that could be improved upon:
  • Make the motion smoother
  • Less wiggle room for the gears - at the moment they can move quite far out of the 3-fold symmetric position
  • Can the gears be made to rotate at different speeds?

comments.text: Whew! After a solid 2hrs of removing supports and 4hrs printing finally got one printed out that looks alright at 60% scale. I wanted it keychain sized for fidgeting with and budget reasons. Surprisingly considering how coarse the thread is, even though I removed ALL supports, it won't rotate, the tolerance between the gears is just too small to allow enough free rotation at 60% scale. I'd need hands made out wrenches to get it to rotate correctly, even with the gears in the correct conformations. Still, really cool!
comments.author: FuzzBot

comments.text: I've had success with SLS prints of this at around 60% scale, but I haven't heard of anyone trying it using an FDM machine. It might loosen up with use?
comments.author: FuzzBot

comments.text: After judicious use of very, very slender knives to pry and shave the gaps slightly larger and smoother, I can now wiggle the loops. I expect full rotation will be possible with more work. Unless it is dissolvable supports, I would not recommend 60% scale PLA print on a printer similar to mine. The gears were barely not fused together. I would bet that full scale would be fine though.

description.text:
My first thing.  Extremely simple design, done in 20 minutes on heekscad (with almost no prior cad experience).  Yes, it is yet another smart phone / MP3 player holder. This one is meant for the horizontal position only.
Edit:  I've added a 2nd file (iStandrevB) that is a three legged version which should work to accommodate the perpendicular direction as well.  I have not yet printed the new version and will likely edit further to cut out some material so it won't use quite as much plastic.
Edit:  As promised, a new version (iStand1.3) with less material.  The notches have been re-sized to 8mm as compared to 12mm on the previous 2 versions.  Assuming Skeinforge won't complain about it, I will print the 1.3 version soon and post pics.
I'm very interested to see any copies of the revB version as I have not yet printed it.  Also, please let me know if you want any variations on this design or would like to request a source file.

I found that attempting to print this without the raft yielded results so horrible on the first few layers that I stopped the print and generated the gcode with the raft enabled.
Edit:  Note that the space between the 2 large legs is ~86mm.  I think that scaling in ReplicatorG by 0.9 would probably be more appropriate than what I have posted for some devices.  The notches are 12mm native, so be aware of this and how your device will fit before scaling.

description.text: A Lumia 820 phone with an embedded cm-ruler.
You can easily trace the embossed numbers and ruler lines with a marker to make them more visible.
Full box organizer for Eldritch Horror + Forsaken Lore + Mountains of Madness

It goes together fairly straightforwardly. Starting with the small card tray in a corner, going counter-clockwise, the next pieces are the large cards short, char tray, large cards tall, monster tray, and then the misc tray. The upper and lower trays go in the middle and the char cards tray goes over top of the char tray/large cards (short) tray.  
This organizer fits all of the expansion up to Mountains of Madness but there is not a lot of room left in the box so no guarantees on it working if they put out more expansions. Hopefully a new expansion would come with a larger box but I suspect not.

title: Simple 'Case' For Raspberry Pi 2 Model B

description.text:
More of a 'bumper' than a 'case' - something to protect the naked board whilst providing good airflow and reasonably open access to the connectors. Includes seat for 30mm fan above the chip.  
I used M3 bolts + nylon stand-offs (16mm above, 6mm below) to complete my 'case'. It's worth noting that on my Pi, the board holes appear to be 2.8mm (7/64"), rather than 3mm, and so required a little drilling out to fit.

title: Azteeg X5 Mount for Kossel Mini

description.text: Was looking for a clean way to mount my Azteeg mini into my Kossel Mini while still being able to access the USB port and SD card. Allows for use of the heat sink under the board, and electronics cooling fan. Fan intake draws near one motor and exhaust near other 2 providing auxually cooling to the motors for those using a heated bed. Play button, usb port, and SD card are accessible from in between the beams on the printer. Holes along the top to tie wires down. The functions scad is the one from josef prusa's i3 github (http://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3). I used the fillet modules in my scad file. *First time designing and first time sharing, so if I'm doing something wrong please someone let me know.

Required Hardware
1 x 20mm Fan
4 x m3 x 25mm Screw (20mm Fan)
4 x m3 x 6mm screw (board to mount)
4 x m3 x 15mm screw (mount to beams)
4 x m3 nuts
12 x m3 washers Mount the fan inside the mount first.
Attach a dongle or the power wires to the green header before mounting the board.
Mount board inside m3 screws should self tap into the plastic

Similar to the last one, but I also need to mount servos facing forward to a shelf.
This thing allows you to mount a server with its plane of rotation in parallel with a shelf that it is sitting on securely.
The extent of the shelf clip is long enough that you could use glue to attach it to the shelf, and it will probably provide enough support for the applied torque.
If this is not good enough, you could drill a couple of holes and use some screws.

Similar to the side facing one:
1) Print one of these out
2) Take your servo's top of bottom off so that it can be fit into the sleeve
3) Press the servo into the sleeve (a very tight fit)
4) Put the top/bottom back on your servo
5) If the friction fit is not good enough for your needs, use some nuts/screws to attach the mounting holes on your servo to the mounting tabs on the sleeve.
6) Put it on your shelf
7) Rejoice!

title: EZStruder modified for soft filaments & TPE

description.text:
UPDATE: base4_fixed.STL includes extra material around the threaded region for the PTC fitting. Modified from Singh336's exemplary work, this remix:
  • Further encloses the filament
  • Reduces clearances around the idler bearing
  • Increases the force imparted by the spring on the idler lever
  • Realigns the idler lever for better contact with the filament
  • Adds a feature that can be tapped for a stock PTC fitting (M5x0.8)
  • Raises the filament entry above the idler lever for easier loading
    • Also included is a flimsy adapter to allow the new cold end to be mounted in the stock position on an unmodified RoStock MAX V2 or on alextoff's slick Dual EZStruder Mount as shown in the photo.

This is a third (and now fourth) revision of my original modification(s) that may require a small amount of adjustment below the idler bearing.  The bearing/filament/hob arrangement is exactly where it should be, however there is an interference at the bottom of the idler bearing travel that may prevent the bearing from seating properly against the filament.  This would require a minimal amount of sanding/cutting to relieve the region, however care must be taken to remove only that material that presents an issue and no more.  
The production version of this item was printed on our uPrintSE with solid infill.

title: Coke Bottle Lid - With Siphon Tubes

description.text:
This is a custom lid for a coke bottle (tested with a 2 litre bottle). It has 2 siphon tubes at the top for your use. 
I designed this thing as part of a drinks dispenser. One side of the siphon tube attaches to an air line. The other side has a tube that goes to the bottom of the bottle. Air goes in, liquid comes out (hopefully)

As im using a pressurised system to get the liquids out of the bottles, i needed this to be as air tight as possible. I've found the best settings as follows. Infill: 100%
Shells: 2 (or 3 might be better)
Layer Height: 0.1mm (i've printed successfully at 0.2mm also)
Movement Speed: 80mm/s Once i have the completed part i found using some plumbers tape around the thread of the bottle, helps it to become air tight. I'm pressurising bottles at around 5-7psi and this seems to be working fine.

description.text:
Here is a collection of 3-D dragon curves.
The openSCAD code that generates the curves is  partially parametric.  The lines that generate the dragon curves are replaced by rectangular blocks and one can specify the length, width, and height of the blocks.  An additional parameter is the degree of the curve; allowed values are 1 through 10.
Stl files are provided for  dragon curves of degree 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10.
The openSCAD code that generated the files is dragon_curves_3d.scad.

Curves 4 through 9 are to the same scale; rectangular blocks 5 mm long, 2 mm wide, and 4 mm high replace the lines in the curves. They are printed in red.  Dragon_10.stl is too large to fit my build platform at that scale. I used bricks 3.5 mm long, 2 mm wide and 4 mm high for dragon_10.stl.  It is printed in blue.
The curves can be printed with or without a raft.  They are reasonably sturdy.  Printing without a raft makes a more attractive model.

description.text:
If you get a FasTrack pass (AKA EasyPass/EZPass in non-Californistan jursidictions) they come with some snazzy and fashionable Velcro(tm) strips with adhesive backing and instructions to mount them on the windshield of your car.  Of course we know these things were designed in New Jersey or Seattle because California actually gets sun for a good portion of the year and the adhesive gives out.  When that happens, the device falls off the windshield out of range of the detectors, you drive through a tollbooth and it can't read the pass, then you get  a snotty letter to settle up or get fined.  
Enter the California FasTrack Pass Holder.  This is a doodad designed to hold your FasTrack box behind the rear view mirror, out of  your line of sight but still accessible to change the settings, and not fall off.  It's designed to permit easy removal and reinstallation of the pass without having to remove the mount device.  
There are probably as many windshield/mirror configurations as there are grains of sand in my driver's side floor mat so, as always, I have included the FreeCad source file for your easy modification.

Printed in PLA which slides nice.  40% infill.  I've printed at both .2mm layer height and .3mm.  2 looks a bit sharper but the 3's work great as well and print faster.

title: Arduino Gcode Interpreter for MiniCNC with Z Axis

description.text: A gcode interpreter with x, y, and z axis that can be used with ReplicatorG. It builds on the existing 2-D gcode interpreter by Oliv4945.

This is a very basic g-code interpreter that implements the G00, G01, and M114 commands - enough to draw with a marker, including pen lifts, using the output from a text to g-code program.
I setup the serial replies from the arduino in a basic reprap format to allow ReplicatorG to send the g-codes. This requires that the xml file be copied the the machines folder in the replicatorG directory and the tinycnc be selected as the machine type in the machine menu. Additional Notes:
The interpreter does not remember the previous command - only the previous X, Y, and Z values. A line of X,Y, and/or Z values requires an associated command. It should however correctly handle multiple commands on a single line.
The program includes a defined backlash value of 1 degrees that can be easily changed.
Getting clear text from a marker will probably requires a couple rounds of adjustment to the Z values used the the g-code. Excessive pressure greatly increases the play in the mini CNC (at least in version 0.29).

comments.text: Great work! Do you think this could be easily modified to read lines of Gcode from an SD card instead?
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text: Yes. The programs currently processes gcode text sent one line at a time over serial. With both the Serial and SD libraries using a similar interface (Stream class), it should be a straightforward modification.
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text: In the tinyCNC.xml file, change "COM3" to whatever port ReplicatorG recognizes as your Arduino (for example, mine is /dev/tty.usbmodem1411).  You can find a list to choose from by looking in ReplicatorG Machine-->Connection, write down what your Arduino is, then copy it into the tinyCNC.xml file.
comments.author: aevictory

title: OmniStand Extra Long Filament Spool Rods

description.header: OmniStand Extra Long Filament Spool Rods
description.text: These filament spool rods allow the quick connect OmniStand and Non-Quick Connect OmniStand to hold slightly wider filament spools. These rods were originally part of the OmniStand set but were removed because of potential issues using them inside the printer. See the warning below before using these rods inside the printer. They are perfectly fine to use with the OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand on the outside of the printer. They also work with the OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand but are shorter than the 125 mm long spool rod that comes with that set.

If using the maximum length rod the top hole on the OmniStand can fit spools up to 190x82.5 mm (7.48x3.24"), but heavy filament should not be used with the maximum length rod.  
If using the maximum length rod outside the printer with the OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand, there is no concern when using heavy spools. Spools up to 280x82.5 mm (11.02x3.24") can be used.

The 103 mm long rod fits on either the left or right side. It can hold spools that are 80 mm wide.  
The maximum length 105.5 mm long rod can hold spools that are 82.5 mm wide. On my Dreamer the 105.5 mm long rod only fits on the left side when using inside the printer.
OmniStand Adjustable Filament Spool Stand OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand Non-Quick Connect OmniStand OmniStand Compatible Quick Connect Filament Spool Stands

When used inside the printer, use the 103 and 105.5 mm spool rods with extreme caution! Filament spools heavier than 0.5 kg can possibly bend the plastic filament stands in towards the build plate enough to cause the filament rod's end to touch the build plate. DO NOT OPERATE YOUR PRINTER IF HEAVY FILAMENT MAKES THE SPOOL ROD TOUCH THE BUILD PLATE! I experienced this problem when printing with ColorFabb's 0.75 kg CopperFill filament using the 103 mm rod. The weight of the filament caused my filament rod to touch the build plate, breaking the rod during a print job. I have not had this problem with 0.5 kg spools, or when using the 100 mm spool rod with heavy filament.
Please see the OmniStand for printing details. (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652415)

author: brentarogers

description.text:
How many times have you been in a situation where you wanted to go out and not have to take you wallet with you? As today's technologies advance, we are at a turning point where smart phones and NFC enabled technology are easing our way of life. Today, a person can leave his/her home only needing at the most 3 cards, For example, I.D., bank card and a loyalty card. The Taganize card holder system solves this everyday problem by incorporating a 3 credit card size adapter into the back cover of the Lumia 820. Now anyone can go out with only the cards needed. What's more, by using our uniquely integrated and styled lanyard they will always be under your nose for safe keeping ! Combined with the NFC products and services being launched this summer by Helsinki, Finland based Taganize you can now take your NFC enabled smart phone to a hold new level. Get ready for the world revolution! Breaking News! - Breaking News! - Breaking News! - Breaking News!
For Immediate Release
28 March 2013, Helsinki Finland Teleco's and retailers speak! Desiring to gauge two days of hard work, I brought my "Taganize NFC embedded Credit Card Adapter" to various GMS operators and retailers throughout Helsinki in order to gauge their reaction to my invention and whether or not as "sellers" they believed there to be a market for my creation. Those approached included Nokia Shop, Elisa, Expert, Sonera, Telecom Finland and Gigantti. The number one feature everyone stated they liked was the fact that a lanyard was included within the product. Too many merchants said people were turned away from purchasing a specific brand phone simple because a lanyard could not be used. In one specific example 2 handsets were pulled from a sales persons pocket noting how each included a place to attach a lanyard. The consensus was firm that paying 25â‚¬ to 30â‚¬ for such a unit was reasonable. All the individuals I spoke with on the sales floor felt extremely confident in their ability as sales persons to recommend this product at that price point and to successfully sell it. In two separate discussions today at two different retails stores, sales people showed me comparable product that they had to sell which was similar to the "Taganize NFC embedded Credit Card Adapter" These included product from Golla and Insmat. Pictures have been attached here for review. Of these, one attaches to the belt and the other uses rock climbing attachments to affix a lanyard to it. Mine was endorsed as being the most practical and comfortable to use and operate, while specifically giving the customer what s/he wanted. All agreed that a three card max. was sufficient and that the integrated feature was a great idea because currently people are doing things that aren't to safe or smart..... Of all the conversations I had today my talks with the Elsia representative proved very interesting. Not only did the sales person know the company product line inside and out. The ability to cross sell and up sell was evident in this persons skill set. When I presented my product video demonstrating how a NFC tag was embedded into the unit I was quickly shown the Elisa & Masercard Pay Pass pilot product currently being evaluated. A picture has been included here as well. The idea of being able to "embed" a NFC payment card into a back cover of a smart phone while maintaining a level of anonymity was extremely interesting to consider. In certain perspectives this could lower the anxiety felt after a smart phone was lost or stolen. Who would know what was inside if they could not see it? Finally, I took my product to the Helsinki Public Library located within Lasipalatsi. Here they have products on display in an attempt to collect feedback for the companies creating them. They also have 3D printers available to the general public for personal use. When I showed my product and pointed out that it had been uploaded to Thingiverse, I was told that "sure we can print that for you.... and it will only cost 0.40â‚¬"! Not believing what I just heard I asked for confirmation. Yep, we are a public entity and we only charge for material..... Wow. What times are in store! Your down stairs in Elisa and buy your new smart phone and literally seconds later you can take the stairs to lasipalatsi to print your custom back cover and embed your pay pass..... Watching what happens next will certainly be fun.

description.text:
This is a turbine blower. It fits 540-sized Motors (like KV 3570) with a diameter of about 35.8 mm and 25 mm pitch cicle diameter.
Mine runs with a brushless KV 3570 @ 12,000 rpm. And yes, it blows like hell. :-)
There are two types of housings. One with stands, and one without stands. The turbine rotor fits on both, of course. The inspiration came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39755.
Have fun.

UPDATE 02.2015:  
Re-modeled the Rotor: Enhanced geometry, easier to print. Even better efficiency (tested it with 22,000 rpm ~ 350W).   
Re-modeled the Housing, both "Gehause" and "Basisplatte": Feet are now shorter (thanks to Brian aka. 58webbing for the hint); reinforcing ribs on the baseplate(s) have been new arranged; some minor cosmetic repairs.   
Renamed the files, remöved umlauts. :-)

Update of Update:  
Added one more Rotor. It is more sturdy and fairly easy to print, even with .6 mm nozzles and extrusions like toothpaste.  
Changed the center hole of the mounting plates to match 13 mm diameters of 540 bearing covers.  
Once again some cosmetics.

Update of Update of...: :-) Two new Rotors. I took down the old Designs as they were not efficient enough. The new ones run much quiter and have about 19% more throughput.
Wir the 92-22-type I can achieve about 295m³ per hour @ 6,5A / 24V.

I printed mine with 0.1 mm layers. This is recommendet at least for the rotor, as it has some sharp edges on top of its fins.
Before going to high rp/m, check if your rotor turns free and is not way out of balance.
When your printer is well calibrated and your filament has not the shape of cooked spaghetti, you don't need to balance the rotor at all.
If you have to do some balancing anyway, try this by drilling 1 mm holes through (!) the base of the rotor. Don't even think about glueing somethin on top.

comments.text: This depends a little bit on waht filament you use. I've printed my rotors out of some special PLA blend which is less brittle and has a higher glass point. It's not the mechanical impact which causes the rotor to get loose, it's the motor shaft heating up and slowly melting the PLA.

comments.text: Ah... Infill, not support material. My bad. :-) Well, the best type is slic3r's "honeycomb" at about 40%. The blades are desinged, that a slicer with a fixed extrusion width of .4 mm can slice them seamlessly with two perimeters. So a complete layer will be printed without any retracts and thus the surface will be smooth and clean. For the first layer/top infill I've selected "circular". With these settings the part will come out well balanced and can be flawlessly operated at higher rp/m.

comments.text:
If the design follows all aerodynamical constraints, regarding efficiency, throughput, etc. - yes. It would be nearly impossible to print without soluble support. And most of the hobbyists here do not have an ABS/HiPPS printer (I guess).
in the FDM/PLA world we wouldn't gain anything. The rotor reaches its limits at about 450W. Not because the vanes would break, but the shaft wouldn't be able to transmit the mechanical load anymore. Depending on what type of motor you are using, either the heat of the shaft will kill your rotor or the shaft itself will become loose. In order to get the aerodynamical advantages out of a "professional" designed chamber, it would require a lot more than 450W (it's getting interesting up from 1kW). :-)

In general the "high-flow" type Rotors are a lot quiter than the easy-to-print ones. The "Turbinenrotor..." is a beast. It is designed for less airflow but higher preassure. At 30,000 rpm (on a 650W brushless motor) you can hear it from outside the house.
I recommend to start with one of the high-flow types.

title: TBS Gemini Antenna Mount, FrSky D4R-II

description.text:
TBS Gemini Antenna Mount, designed to work with FrSky D4R-II receiver, or other receivers with wire-lead antenna(s). There are two versions included, one with the 'WiliM' logo, and another without logo. The design goals were to:
  • Create separation between sources of RF noise and the antennas.
  • To orient the two antennas in different directions
  • To create a mount that would allow easy removal of the top & bottom covers without having to remove the antennas
  • To fit in the stock Gemini case, without having to go through a lot of hassle.
    = Basically an out-of-the way antenna mount, that provides good antenna placement, is easy to install and use, is completely reversible, and fits properly and easily into the stock carrying case. :o)
    • The antenna mount is a friction fit - it simply presses into place. No fasteners are necessary. The first time it goes in, the fit should feel tight. I have installed and removed mine many times, and flown with it as well; the fit has remained tight. To complete installation, you'll need one antenna mast cut to length. Some silicon tubing to join the antenna masts to the antenna holder. I printed mine on a Solidoodle 4, at 0.3 resolution, 1.0 infill. I hope you like it and find it useful!

To complete installation, you'll need two antenna masts cut to length (one antenna tube is long enough to make tubes appropriate for both stock D4R-II antennas). You will also need some silicon tubing to join the antenna masts to the antenna holder. I printed mine on a Solidoodle 4, at 0.3 resolution, 1.0 infill. Thread the antenna wires through the two large holes in the mount.
Snap the mount in place from underneath.
Thread the antennas into the small hole in the back of the mount; depending on your printer, you may need to open up the holes a bit by hand. Cut two pieces of silicon fuel tubing (available at hobby stores), about 20mm each. Thread the antenna wires through them, and push the silicon tube over the ends of the antenna holder. Cut two pieces of RC antenna tube (available at hobby stores), about 4-5" each. Thread the antenna wires through them, and twist them into the end of the silicon tube. Go and fly!

The TBS Gemini Body Retention System was designed to:
  • Protect the PCB/ESC traces from the sharp edges of the lexan cover, particularly when landing.
  • To create an easy to install and use way of installing and removing the top and bottom lexan covers.
  • To minimize the chances of losing the elastics/o-rings.
  • To do all that and still fit in the Gemini travel case.
    • Two loops and two hooks are printed, and attached to the top edge of the bottom lexan cover with Goop (available at home improvement stores). An o-ring is attached to each loop, stretched across the top cover, then attached to the hoop on the opposite side of the cover. I printed these parts on my Solidoodle 4, with 0.3mm resolution, and 1.0 infill. In addition to the printed parts, some Goop adhesive and some 2.75-3.25" elastics or o-rings are required. In addition to the loop/hook/o-rings, I recommend installing a strip of silicon fuel tubing (available at RC hobby stores), along the perimeter of the bottom lexan cover. The silicon will protect the PCB/ESC traces from impacts from the edge of the lexan cover, particularly during landings. See the instructions for more information! I hope you find these parts helpful. Enjoy!
  • WillM

• Print the parts; you will need 2 of each.

  • Install the top and bottom lexan covers and choose where you would like the hooks & loops installed. If you are going to install silicon tubing, do this first. The silicon tubing needs to be slit lenth-wise, an then placed along the edge of the bottom cover. The hooks and loops should be placed just below the silicon tubing, not contacting it. Mine are placed approximately 2mm below the silicon tubing.

  • Remove the bottom lexan cover. Scuff the area where the hooks and loops will mount. This will help the Goop (adhesive) achieve better adhesion to the lexan.

  • Follow the Goop's direction to install the loops. I took my time and did them one at a time, following the directions, and holding each hook or loop in place for the first few minutes. After that, I removed the silicon tubing to get it out of the way. Do this for both hooks and both loops.

  • Once the Goop has dried, slip one end of an elastic or o-ring through one of the loops, from the bottom, poking it through about an inch. This take the other end of the o-ring/elastic, and pass it through the loop, then draw it tight. This will keep the elastic/o-ring from getting lost. Do this for both loops.

  • With both the top and bottom lexan covers installed (and the silicon tube, if you are using it), stretch the elastic/o-ring over the top cover, and slip it over the loop. You should not need to stretch the elastic/o-ring very much. Only a little pressure is necessary to keep the parts in place, and anything more than that could damage the fragile lexan cover. The front elastic/o-ring will need to be approximately 1/2" longer than the rear. I used 2 equal length o-rings for the front and back, but added a short o-ring to the front. The large o-rings were 3.25" OD, and the short one 1.25" OD. Both were 1/16" thick.
    • Go and fly! I hope you find this helpful.

I needed a way to turn my 3d printers off after they were done printing. This box goes inline to up to two printers. The external control box was made from this part:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667503 This box allows you to turn off the printers after a set amount of time.

Be very careful. Youw ill be working with line voltage in this project. This can be dangerous. Do not work on this when alone in case something goes wrong. Print the box. To assemble the box, you will need: 1 - 3d printed box
2 - 3d printed relay retainer plate
3 - 3d printed cover
4 - relay board http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KTEN3TM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00
5 - Inlet plug http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0050HH70E/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01
6 - Standard wall power outlet
7 - Standard wall cover plate
8 - rj45 jack http://www.amazon.com/Keystone-Cat5e-Network-Ethernet-Punchdown/dp/B00CJGJ1MG/ref=sr_1_32?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1423113450&sr=1-32&keywords=rj-45
9 - network wire. You can cut up a piece of network for this.
10 - 18 gauge or thicker wire for moving the power. Place the relay board in the box. Conect the power through the switch. Break the tabs off of the outlet receptacle. Run both legs of the AC through the relays to the swtich to ensure that you are switching the power on and off. Hook up the wires on the relay board to the rj45. Build the LCD box. Add the arduino. Program it with the supplied arduino sketch. Connect the rj-45 connector to the box. Power it up in a safe place.

Using 4 of these lid spacers on the 4 corners below the lid will create a 7 mm air gap between the lid and the Dreamer's main body. This helps prevent heat build-up inside the Dreamer. This is useful when you want to keep dust off your print but also want to cool down your print environment. The lid spacers are designed to be printed with ABS. They simply snap into place over the existing corner lid guides. Note that I have an older FlashForge Dreamer with the foggy door. These fit my model perfectly. title: FlashForge Dreamer Side Panel Fan Mount

description.header: FlashForge Dreamer Side Panel Fan Mount
description.text: The side panel fan mounts are designed to replace the Dreamer's snap in side panels allowing you to mount two 80x80x15mm fans on the left and right side of the Dreamer as I have done with my own Dreamer. It's possible these MIGHT fit the Dremel as well. Two styles of fan mounts are included. The flat side panel fan mount is designed for the left side. Because it's flat on the outside, it allows the printer to stand on it's left side wall when doing maintenance, which is something I do often. The outset side panel fan mount is typically mounted on the right side, giving better clearance for the internal parts. I don't put this on the left side because I usually lay my printer on it's left side when doing maintenance. It's not good to stand the printer on it's left side to do maintenance if using the outset side panel, because the outset panel will break. Note: the photos are outdated, showing my older design. The wiring diagram shows how I wired up my 4 extra fans using a step down converter, a thermostat, and a switch to override the thermostat (see the FlashForge Dreamer Thermostat Mount for details).

FlashForge Dreamer Thermostat Mount found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:682667 FlashForge Dreamer Short Fan Filament Guide Clip found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667620

title: FlashForge Dreamer Short Fan Filament Guide Clip

description.header: FlashForge Dreamer Short Fan Filament Guide Clip
description.text: These are used to clip the filament guide tubes onto the fans on the back of the Dreamer. There are 2 clips: A and B. Both A and B are used on the right and left fan. Take a look at the photo to see the proper positioning for the clips on the fans. My Dreamer is the older model with a foggy door that did NOT include fans on the back. I added 4 of my own 80x80x15mm fans on the back and sides (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:667612) of my Dreamer for added cooling. Once I did that, my original filament guide tube clips no longer fit on the back. So I had to create these new shorter filament guide tube clamps. They work well. Note: I am powering my 4 custom added fans using the extra power terminals inside my FlashForge Dreamer's power supply. They are attached to a switch and thermostat I also added so that I can manually turn them on or have my thermostat turn them on automatically. The power supply my Dreamer came with supplies enough power to run 4 additional 80x80x15mm fans, 4 additional short 24 volt LED light strips, and a thermostat! Pretty sweet!

title: Dual Axis Rotational Casting Machine (AKA Coin Caster)Prototype

description.text:
This Machine is an an experimental prototype created for the purpose making light weight hollow castings from rapid setting resins cast into rubber molds.
-Centrifugal force allows liquids to flow evenly to all interior surfaces of an mold and cures to an solid state while in motion within minutes.
  • ideally the motion of rotation could be optimized toward the shape of an object and the speed of an curing material so that the casting would have even wall thickness no greater than necessary to support the structure of the shape.
    _This process would also lend it self well to casting waxes into rubber molds to produce patterns in an lost wax process for metal casting in an foundry situation.

This machine was made largely made from scrap materials lying around on the floor of an commercial sign shop for under $ 300. I would not necessarily recommend trying to build such a device by following closely as to what is now pictured but rather do embrace the concept of it to suit your needs.
My goal at this point would be to create an smaller version driven with stepper motors so that complex shapes could be positioned with particular range of motions accurately and repeatedly.Once an stepper version is perfected I would like to scale the design up again and maybe run it with servos.
This machine is not an great design just yet although it was an success .It produced quality castings is capable of spinning molds upwards of 100lbs.
Most of the guts of this device can be gotten cheaply off the shelf even from an flea market or garage sale with the exception of one element which is the rotating contactor which allows power to travel through the horizontal axis while in motion to run an 1/3 hp motor that drives the spinning tables which the molds get mounted to.I believe it was an Dynatron Armature salvaged from an rotating sign.

A peel-off module for zebra label printers created for the company I work for (Harrier LLC) because the ones provided by Zebra are crappy and cost a lot to replace.  
Fins have been altered to be stronger but still fit in the printer.  
Print requires small support structures for the edge overhangs which are required to fit properly into the printer.

A reworking of sorenrd's "Thinking Trooper" See images for before/after comparison of supports and internal structure.
  • Re-combined head onto model removing all overlapping geometry as original caused a lot of internal support structures and excess material to be used.
  • Reduced overhangs on toes, robe, back of the head, and neck to remove the need for majority of support structures.
    • Recommend printing with a 20 degree incline to remove the facial support structure needed for the top of the helmet https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1RXNeIx-nHQ&feature=youtu.be

description.text:
Modified existing design. Added 2 more attachments to frame for more solid attachment. Moved motor upwards a bit so that the Y-belt is reasonably horizontal, as i had a 0.8 micrometer difference each millimeter caused by attachment to printbed being higher located than the wheel. Made holes saving out plastic a tad smaller for stronger object. Wasn't luxury.
Also made part a tad larger as the original which was 70 mm, it didn't fit. This one is 72 mm. So first measure whether that's the distance you need, as 72 mm means screwholes are based upon 70 mm distance between the extrusions. Note some plastic gets underneath extrusion. This isn't a problem for the default Mendelmaxes as it already rests onto plastic, otherwise modify it in the openscad file also attached here. The original part would mean you need 68 mm between the 2 extrusions which is a weird number. Not sure how that could've worked for anybody, but well there is many incarnations of mendelmax!

Make sure you accurately measure how much up or down you want to put the motor to get a horizontal moving y-belt.
In orange pla part weighs 42 grams with settings how i printed it.

remixed_from.title: Mobius Wide Angle Lens (Lens B) Holder

description.text:
Project is currently documented on http://360cameraonline.com/ 360 video currently is a hard thing to pull of and requires investing in multiple cameras. This concept saves a lot of money considering its using mobius camera instead of expensive GoPro's (most 360 3D printed rigs are based on GoPro). 3D Printing a camera rig saves a lot of time, and its super hard to manually make this rig so that each lens is exactly at a 51 degree. The rig enables to shoot panoramic 360 3D footage. Lenses are rotated horizontaly for greater field of view. Based on Jim Watters design http://photocreations.ca/3D/mobius_camera_rig.html
Prints fine on a standard 20mm x 20mm build plate.

• Print stil files.
  • Buy 14 cheap mobius cameras with wide Lens B + 14 exenstion cables for lens seperation the body of the cameras are out of the way - more compact camera
  • Put everything together
  • Add one or two GoPro for top view strap with rubber bands
  • Figure out a way to start recording all at the same time or use Mobius continuous recording. After 5 minutes of run time all the footage should be in sync. If anyone has an idea how to do this by arduino or any other way let me know!
  • Enjoy! :)

comments.text: I now have a 360 Mobius setup built  ... trying Video Stitch and Autopano, is there existing templates and/or Mobius C2 lens specs to be used to enable this software to do a decent job?  I can't find the necessary C2 lens specs online?  Am thinking I may need to resort to manual stitching of video using ptgui software?

description.text: Connector to Ikea wooden train tracks, that can be used with Duplo bricks. My friends son is delighted :) have fun :) I'v added original file from DesingSpark if you want to modify something.

When I first saw the PiGRRL released by Adafruit I knew that I had to build one, but I wanted to tweak it a little, then part way through my design process Adafruit upped their game and released the [Super Game Pi]( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:629873 )! But I had a problem, it was too large for my Printrbot! D:
So I designed this, my version of the Super Game Pi , which I call the Super Game PiSP, because I based the basic shape off of the PSP. I had a few things in mind making it, namely:
  • It had to print on my Printrbot Simple Metal ( ~ 150mm ^3 volume )
  • I wanted to reduce the visibility of screws in the design ( my component mounting screws are internal )
  • I wanted a more rounded design
  • I wanted the battery to be internal
  • I wanted to use the Pi B+ ( and now it can use the Pi 2 B ! :D )
  • I wanted to use tac buttons , and not have to cut up a game controller PCB
    • So with those in mind I created this! The electronics and setup are nearly identical to the guide for the Super Game Pi https://learn.adafruit.com/super-game-pi , except I used a Pi B+ , and tac switches instead of a hacked up game pad I'll post more detailed information later, but I want to get this released before I head to work! ( More detailed information now available on the instructions page, as well as pictures of the internals ) Inspired by, but not directly derived from the Super Game Pi ( used it as reference for quite a few measurements )

The assembly of this Thing is done entirely with 3/8 4-40 Machine screws, Two of which had to be cut off short unfortunately ( though it could work properly by not screwing them in entirely ) You will need a 4-40 tap to tap all of the screw holes. Assemble the bottom three pieces together , and the top three pieces together. Then install the electronics. The screen slides into place, but you may need to flex the top piece slightly to get it to fit, and you may wish to secure it in place with a small amount of hot glue. The speakers and power switch will need to be secured with a small amount of hot glue. the battery pack is not secured in place, it is held in place by the PCB for the buttons above it when the enclosure is closed. All of the other pieces are held in place with machine screws. ** Note as Juper pointed out, you will need to cut the traces in between the button leads on your PCB for the Blue and Yellow buttons to prevent them from shorting out across each other. Once all of the electronics are installed, carefully connect the top to the bottom and screw the enclosure shut. The electronics used in this project are:
  • Colorful Round Tactile Button Switch Assortment - 15 pack
  • Raspberry Pi Model B+ 512MB RAM OR Raspberry Pi 2 - Model B - ARMv7 with 1G RAM
  • TFP401 HDMI/DVI Decoder to 40-Pin TTL Breakout - Without Touch
  • 5.0" 40-pin 800x480 TFT Display without Touchscreen
  • Analog 2-axis Thumb Joystick with Select Button + Breakout Board
  • Cupcade Adapter PCB + Parts Pack
  • Stereo 2.8W Class D Audio Amplifier - I2C Control AGC - TPA2016
  • PowerBoost 500 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 500mA+
  • Lithium Ion Battery Pack - 3.7V 6600mAh
  • Mini Metal Speaker w/ Wires - 8 ohm 0.5W
  • 40-pin FPC Extension Board + 200mm Cable
  • HDMI Flat Cable - 1 foot / 30cm long
    Highly recommend getting a short HDMI cable, I cut a long one and soldered it back together , which is what the blob of hotglue over the HDMI decoder is encasing
  • Right-Angle 3.5mm Stereo Plug to Pigtail Cable
  • Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch
    • You will also need some through hole PCB to cut up and mount the buttons onto, such as the
    Adafruit Perma-Proto Full-sized Breadboard PCB - Single I had an old Radio Shack one left over. The software setup and electronics connections are very well explained in the Adafruit Super Game Pi Write up

comments.text: Okay, after looking over the documentation and getting the multi-meter out, I would like to point out what has already been written and observed in the initial instructions. The Adafruit breadboard, has tracers and all the buttons will short out if the tracers are not removed since they share a common ground. That is to say, all 5 buttons will short out and will not read. I am going to go purchase a simple breadboard with no tracers at Radio Shack. I will post an update if this fixes the issue. I am confident that it will since single buttons will work if wired individually.
comments.author: Grimmbly

comments.text: Looks like you have to wire the positive and ground contact wires diagonally. For example, left top; right top; left bottom; right bottom; --- if you wire left top ground and right top positive = short in your connection and will short all 5 buttons since they share a common ground. Also the tracers need to be cut out if you are using the Adafruit bread/perfboard and this included in the modified directions for this project. @ Carisabana please add my first comment to your instructions to help further project doers on this project.

comments.text:
Hi Carasibana,
I've been working on this project and was very excited to see it done, but then I hit a snag, the TFP401 HDMI/DVI Decoder to 40-Pin TTL Breakout's connection to the 40-pin FPC 200mm Cable is extremely weak and touchy. When I closed it all up the screen's colors would shift all around and the only way to fix it was to push the cable's end down harder into the decoder. I was thinking about ordering a new decoder, would that fix the problem? If not, what suggestions do you have?
comments.author: Jazeisloft7

comments.text: it sounds like your connector is a bit loose for the ribbon cable. the only thing I can think of to suggest aside from ordering a new decoder would be to try taking a small strip of thin plastic , cutting it to the width of the ribbon cable , and inserting it into the connector with the cable ( on the side without the actual electrical connectors of course ). Hopefully that would add some bulk to the cable , and allows the connector on the decoder to grab onto it more firmly.
comments.author: Jazeisloft7

comments.text:
I have been trying to put this together and I have a question. How did you handle the HDMI cord because I can't get it to fit?

comments.text: I want to make this but I want to use a D-pad rather than a joystick.. is there any kind of dpad breakout board to replace this with? I can use the D-pad from an SNES/NES controller and re-model that one STL to fit it if this were possible.
comments.author: 3DPrintingLive

comments.text: Absolutely, the cupcade adapter basically turns the joystick into a D-Pad anyway, it would just be a matter of connecting up buttons to act as a D pad, tying a common ground to them , and attaching a connection from each of them to the Raspberry pi where the cupcade adapter is connected. You could make your own with Tact-switches , or use one out of a game controller and trace the connections.

description.text: We created a plastic mug using 123D design. We successfully printed it using our school 3D printer. We used red PLA filament. It took approximately 2 hours to print. It is a small mug.

I found the stock landing gear too fragile, and the more durable gear broke too.  Seems like all my breaks occured due to forward flight, not hard landings.  
When FPV racing it can be hard to detirmine your altitude.  I would frequently scrape the ground, and the gear would break.  Hopefully this will allow me to slide without breaking, and hopefully still strong enough for the occasional hard landing.  
Success!  I've flown two intense sessions practicing for an upcoming race, several scrapes, and a couple crashes...the gear held together!

Print two, and glue or weld them in the center.  If you lay it down it will print without support.  
I printed in ABS at 50% fill.
